items.title: Trump says US 'will run' Venezuela after strikes
items.description: The US has "captured" Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife during an early-morning raid, which saw US military strike targets within the capital Caracas and in several other states. Follow live.

items.title: America's 250th birthday party will serve up a toxic brew of exceptionalism
items.description: It is entirely fitting that the US is so splintered on its semiquincentennial. Division, for the lion's share of its history, has been its default.

items.title: Hindus 'living in fear' after man's public lynching for alleged blasphemy
items.description: Four Hindu men have been killed in Muslim-majority Bangladesh in just over two weeks, and several houses have been burned, leaving the minority community traumatised and fearing for their lives.

items.title: Tourists stranded, dozens of roads closed as showers continue in outback Queensland
items.description: Tourists are stranded in towns dotted across north-west Queensland as rain continues to keep major rivers in flood.

items.title: A station and infamous murders: What happened to Sydney's Macdonaldtown?
items.description: It's the suburb in Sydney that no longer exists — except for a train station — but did it disappear because of scandalous murders or was it just to increase property prices?

items.title: Australian brands still dealing with 'the wild west' of Trump's tariffs
items.description: From de minimis to beef tariffs, Aussie exporters are preparing for another "wild" year.

items.title: Amid a population crisis, this island needs migrants to keep its industry alive
items.description: The Japanese island of Etajima's oyster industry relies almost entirely on foreign workers due to its aging population.

items.title: How you're already relying on AI, even if you think you're not
items.description: Artificial intelligence is a controversial subject, but as the debate rages it is already being used by ACT government departments, doctors and the people running firefighting operations.

items.title: On Pakistan's roof of the world, a new generation of female climbers emerge
items.description: Pakistani women are hiking some of the world's tallest mountains and glacier trails, claiming a space that has long been out of reach.

items.title: Traditional romance stories get a First Nations twist with 'choc-lit'
items.description: An anthology of love stories written by First Nations people is in the works with stories of blak love, joy, and connection capitalising on the fastest growing literary genre in the world.

items.title: Man told to pay $120,000 over unauthorised backyard cheese business
items.description: An Adelaide retiree who continually ignored orders to remove an unauthorised backyard cheesemaking facility from his suburban home is ordered to pay more than $120,000 in costs, after being found guilty of contempt of court.

items.title: Summer is here but this town's pub is closed for the first time in 140 years
items.description: For the first time in almost 140 years, Toora's historic pub did not trade over the festive season, leaving locals and visitors with nowhere to drink.

items.title: Is butter, margarine or nut spread the best choice?
items.description: You might have a personal preference for which spread you use at home, but experts say there are health considerations for which one you use.

items.title: Former North Melbourne AFL player Phoenix Spicer dies aged 23
items.description: Phoenix Spicer, who played 12 AFL matches for North Melbourne, has died at the age of 23.

items.title: Police seek help after alleged sexual assault in Melbourne laneway on January 1
items.description: Police seek public assistance to locate a 22-year-old French man who allegedly sexually assaulted a woman in a Melbourne laneway in the early hours of New Year's Day.

items.title: How Hillary made history again with an 'arrogant' dash to the South Pole
items.description: Less than five years after conquering Mount Everest, legendary explorer Sir Edmund Hillary wanted to make history again in Antarctica.

items.title: Quiz: How well do you know these places around the world?
items.description: Your task in the ABC Places quiz is to correctly identify the location shown in each of 10 photos. Grab your passport and let's go.

items.title: Friends keep teenage pact to retire in the outback together
items.description: Veronica and Wendy made a pact as teenagers to move back to their hometown to retire together. More than 40 years later they have kept their promise.

items.title: Worker dies in Central Queensland mine following roof collapse
items.description: A worker has died after a roof collapse at the Curragh mining complex in Central Queensland.

items.title: How braille music opens up the music world for blind people
items.description: In the 1820s, Louis Braille devised a raised-dot system of letters, numbers and musical notation. 200 years later, it’s still opening the music world for blind musicians.

items.title: De Minaur unfazed by United Cup loss in Australian Open build-up
items.description: Alex de Minaur is not concerned about his Australian Open preparations, believing he can "flip that switch" after recording his first career defeat to Casper Ruud.

items.title: Brisbane man training to take on Mount Everest world record
items.description: Oliver Foran struggled with his mental health after losing his mother to cancer. Now, he is training to set a world record while raising money and awareness for youth mental health.

items.title: Early eye testing helped Lucy avoid blindness
items.description: A group of researchers is calling on the South Australian government to implement a universal vision screening program for all children attending preschools or day care centres.

items.title: One Australian dead, another badly injured after Bali scooter crash
items.description: DFAT is supporting the families of a NSW Central Coast man killed and a woman injured in a scooter crash in Bali.

items.title: Snowy Mountains rodeo celebrates 80 years
items.description: As the Tumbarumba Rodeo celebrates its 80th year, the Rial family have held on for the longest ride of them all.
